questions.question: Which journal entry records the purchase of office supplies on account?
questions.correctAnswer: Debit Supplies, Credit Accounts Payable
questions.explanation: Purchasing supplies on account increases assets (Supplies) and creates a liability (Accounts Payable). Cash is not affected.

questions.question: A company received $1,000 from a customer for services to be performed next month. How should this be journalized?
options: Debit Accounts Receivable, Credit Service Revenue
questions.correctAnswer: Debit Cash, Credit Unearned Revenue
questions.explanation: Cash is received, but revenue is not earned yet, so a liability (Unearned Revenue) is credited.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding journal entries?
options: Each entry must have at least one debit and one credit
Journal entries do not require explanations
questions.correctAnswer: Each entry must have at least one debit and one credit
questions.explanation: The fundamental accounting rule is that debits must equal credits in every journal entry.

questions.question: An error occurred where a $500 payment to a vendor was debited to Accounts Payable and credited to Cash. What type of error is this?
questions.correctAnswer: Correct entry
questions.explanation: Debiting Accounts Payable reduces the liability and crediting Cash reduces the asset correctly.

questions.question: Why is it important to journalizing? (Challenging)
options: It creates a chronological record of transactions
It eliminates the need for ledgers
questions.correctAnswer: It creates a chronological record of transactions
questions.explanation: Journalizing provides a chronological record of transactions, creating an audit trail and supporting accurate posting to ledgers.

questions.question: How does a manager typically journalize transactions?
options: By recording each transaction chronologically in the journal
By delegating all accounting tasks to external auditors
By posting entries directly to financial statements
questions.correctAnswer: By recording each transaction chronologically in the journal
questions.explanation: Journalizing means recording transactions in the journal in chronological order so they can be posted to the ledger.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of journalizing?
options: To provide a chronological record of business transactions
To value inventory at market price
questions.correctAnswer: To provide a chronological record of business transactions
questions.explanation: The primary purpose of journalizing is to record each transaction chronologically, producing a reliable audit trail for posting and review.

questions.question: Which account type normally has a credit balance?
questions.correctAnswer: Revenue
questions.explanation: Revenues and liabilities normally have credit balances, while assets and expenses normally have debit balances.

questions.question: Rent expense is classified as which type of account?

questions.question: Prepaid insurance is an example of which account type?

questions.question: Which type of business ownership has unlimited personal liability?
questions.correctAnswer: Sole proprietorship
questions.explanation: In a sole proprietorship, the owner is personally responsible for all business debts.

questions.question: Which method of depreciation allocates an equal expense each year?
questions.correctAnswer: Straight-line
questions.explanation: Straight-line depreciation spreads the cost of an asset evenly over its useful life.

questions.question: Which is an advantage of computerized accounting over manual systems?
questions.correctAnswer: Faster processing and reporting
questions.explanation: Computerized systems speed up data processing and allow automatic report generation.

questions.question: Which of the following violates accounting ethics?
options: Recording revenue before it is earned
questions.correctAnswer: Recording revenue before it is earned
questions.explanation: Recognizing revenue prematurely misstates financial statements and breaches ethical standards.

questions.question: A company purchases equipment for $5,000 cash. What is the correct journal entry?
questions.correctAnswer: Debit Equipment, Credit Cash
questions.explanation: Equipment is an asset, so it is debited, and cash decreases, so it is credited.

questions.question: Utilities payable is classified as which type of account?
questions.correctAnswer: Liability
questions.explanation: Payables represent obligations, so Utilities Payable is a liability.

questions.question: Which principle requires recording assets at their original cost?
questions.correctAnswer: Cost Principle
questions.explanation: The cost principle requires assets to be recorded at their historical cost.

questions.question: Which of the following reduces net income?
questions.correctAnswer: Expenses
questions.explanation: Expenses reduce net income, while revenue increases it. Owner investments do not affect income.

questions.question: Posting ensures that:
options: All journal entries are balanced in the ledger
Trial balance errors are eliminated automatically
questions.correctAnswer: All journal entries are balanced in the ledger
questions.explanation: Posting transfers information from journals to ledger accounts so balances can be tracked accurately.

questions.question: Which of the following is a long-term liability?
questions.correctAnswer: Mortgage Payable
questions.explanation: Long-term liabilities are due in more than one year; mortgages typically qualify.

questions.question: Adjusting entries are placed in which column of the worksheet?
questions.correctAnswer: Adjustment columns
questions.explanation: Adjustment columns are used to record necessary changes before preparing financial statements.

questions.question: A check written by the company has not cleared the bank yet. This is called a:
questions.correctAnswer: Outstanding check
questions.explanation: Outstanding checks are written and recorded by the company but have not yet cleared the bank.

questions.question: Which of the following is withheld from an employee’s paycheck?
questions.correctAnswer: FICA taxes
questions.explanation: FICA taxes are deducted from employees’ wages for Social Security and Medicare.

questions.question: Which type of business ownership allows stockholders to limit personal liability?
questions.correctAnswer: Corporation
questions.explanation: In a corporation, shareholders’ liability is limited to their investment in the company.

questions.question: Units of production depreciation depends on:
questions.correctAnswer: Usage or output
questions.explanation: Units of production depreciation allocates cost based on actual use or production of the asset.

questions.question: Which is true about computerized accounting systems?
questions.correctAnswer: Reports are generated faster
questions.explanation: Computerized systems automate reporting, making it faster and more efficient than manual methods.

questions.question: Falsifying financial records is considered:
questions.correctAnswer: Fraud
questions.explanation: Falsifying records misrepresents financial statements and violates ethical and legal standards.

questions.question: Which of the following affects both income statement and balance sheet?
questions.correctAnswer: Revenue earned on credit
questions.explanation: Revenue increases net income (income statement) and also increases Accounts Receivable (balance sheet).

questions.question: Which of the following is true about posting?
options: Balances in ledger accounts are updated
Errors in journals are automatically corrected
questions.correctAnswer: Balances in ledger accounts are updated
questions.explanation: Posting transfers journal entry amounts to ledger accounts, allowing for updated balances.

questions.question: A customer returns merchandise previously sold on credit. Which journal entry is correct?
options: Debit Sales Returns, Credit Accounts Receivable
questions.correctAnswer: Debit Sales Returns, Credit Accounts Receivable
questions.explanation: Sales returns reduce revenue and accounts receivable when goods are returned.

questions.question: Unearned revenue is classified as a:
questions.correctAnswer: Liability
questions.explanation: Unearned revenue represents money received for services not yet performed, creating a liability.

questions.question: The revenue recognition principle requires revenue to be recorded when:
questions.correctAnswer: Services are performed
questions.explanation: Revenue is recognized when earned, not necessarily when cash is collected.

questions.question: Which scenario requires adjusting entries to properly report income?
questions.correctAnswer: Prepaid expenses
questions.explanation: Prepaid expenses must be allocated to the correct period to accurately report income.

questions.question: After posting journal entries, the next step is usually:
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare trial balance
questions.explanation: A trial balance verifies that all debits and credits are equal after posting.

questions.question: Which account is reported under current liabilities?
questions.correctAnswer: Accounts Payable
questions.explanation: Current liabilities are obligations due within one year, such as accounts payable.

questions.question: Which worksheet column shows adjusted balances for financial statement preparation?
questions.correctAnswer: Balance Sheet columns
questions.explanation: Adjusted balances are extended to the Balance Sheet and Income Statement columns to prepare financial statements.

questions.question: Which item would be added to the book balance during bank reconciliation?
questions.correctAnswer: Bank error that understated deposits
questions.explanation: Errors that understate the book balance must be added to correct the balance.

questions.question: Employer payroll taxes are recorded as:
questions.correctAnswer: Expense
questions.explanation: Employer payroll taxes are a business expense incurred in paying employees.
